fields.public_field_1_en: You're walking to work from the bus stop when your phone rings. It's the director of the town's affordable housing developer
fields.public_field_2_en: I'll pick up.

fields.public_field_1_en: John, the affordable Housing Non-profit Director
fields.public_field_2_en: Hi Mayor! The local university just released a report on the future of housing costs in Bayville. Did you know that by 2050, the average family in our town will spend almost half of their income on housing?
fields.public_field_3_en: That’s concerning. We need to do something right now.

fields.public_field_1_en: How are you going to prevent that from happening?
fields.public_field_2_en: Make a decision
Fund affordable housing production and preservation
fields.public_field_3_en: Raise taxes to generate funds to build a broad range of permanently affordable housing.
fields.public_field_4_en: This would provide a regular stream of funds to address the need for affordable housing.
fields.public_field_5_en: Opponents say that taxes raise the cost of living for everyone and that other funding sources should be used.
fields.public_field_8_en: Require 20 percent of all new housing to be affordable
fields.public_field_9_en: Adopt regulations that require twenty percent of all newly constructed units to be rented at below-market rents.
fields.public_field_10_en: This provides a growing supply of affordable housing that is distributed throughout the region.
fields.public_field_11_en: Opponents say this strategy could limit the total amount of housing that is built by increasing the costs to developers.
fields.public_field_15_en: Implement a suite of renter protection strategies to prevent large rent increases and protect tenants from discrimination by landlords.
fields.public_field_16_en: This strategy would promote more affordable rents and greater stability for renters.
fields.public_field_17_en: Opponents say renter protections could cause some landlords to stop renting out their properties, reducing the overall housing supply.

fields.public_field_1_en:
Great! You selected Strategy 1: Streamline accessory dwelling units and spent <coins_spent> coins from your budget.

You selected fund affordable housing production and preservation! Implementing this strategy in the Bay Area is estimated to produce between 400 and 600 new permanently affordable rental units each year. That’s around 11,000 to 17,000 units between now and 2050. Thousands more already affordable units were maintained and remained affordable.

Now you only have <coins_left> coins to implement strategies related to 2 other housing issues. Don’t spent too much!
fields.public_field_2_en: Build affordable housing
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.

fields.public_field_1_en:
Great! You selected Strategy 2: Require 20 percent of all new housing to be affordable.

You selected require 20 percent of all new housing to be affordable! Implementing this strategy in the Bay Area is estimated to produce between 2,400 and 4,000 new permanently affordable rental units each year. That’s around 70,000 to 100,000 units between now and 2050. However, this policy only improved affordability for those that were able to move to these new units and did not help people afford to stay in their existing homes.

Now you only have <coins_left> coins to implement strategies related to 2 other housing issues. Don’t spent too much!
fields.public_field_2_en: Build ADUs
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.

fields.public_field_1_en:
Great! You selected Strategy 3: Increase renter protections and spent <coins_spent> coins from your budget.

You selected increase renter protections! A similar set of policies implemented in Portland, Oregon capped annual rent increases at 2% and resulted in a fifteen percent decrease in no-fault evictions. 

Now you only have <coins_left> coins to implement strategies related to 2 other housing issues. Don’t spent too much!
fields.public_field_2_en: Renter protections
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.

fields.public_field_1_en: The first thing on your agenda today is a meeting with the citizens’ advisory council to discuss your housing plan. This group always has a lot to say, but they have some good advice
fields.public_field_2_en: Attend Meeting

fields.public_field_1_en: Resident 1
fields.public_field_2_en:
Our town owns some land at the edge of town that is currently sitting vacant with no plans for future use.
Since our town already owns that land, building housing there would be cheaper and faster than if we had to find a site and buy it first. We could build there ourselves or sell the land to an affordable housing developer. 
What do you think?

fields.public_field_1_en: Resident 2
fields.public_field_2_en:
I like that idea, but I have another idea that could work for the housing plan.
There are several malls around town that have seen better days. Storefronts have been empty for months and overall more customers are choosing to shop online. These malls are on large lots located in the middle of town.
We could work with the mall owners to build vibrant neighborhoods that have housing, workplaces, parks, and stores.

fields.public_field_1_en: Which sites would you prioritize for reuse and redevelopment?
fields.public_field_2_en: Repurpose public land to build housing
fields.public_field_3_en: Pass state legislation to reduce the barriers to development for housing on vacant and underused public land.
fields.public_field_4_en: This land could be developed by cities or sold to developers under the condition that a certain number of affordable units are built or certain amenities are provided.
fields.public_field_5_en: Opponents say that selling public land is potentially risky and could make it more difficult to build other public facilities like parks or schools to meet future demand.
fields.public_field_9_en: Work with cities and property owners to redevelop vacant and under-performing shopping centers into mixed-income neighborhoods.
fields.public_field_10_en: This land could be acquired for a lower-cost and is often located near existing public transportation.
fields.public_field_11_en: Opponents say the number of potential sites is too small to fully address the need for new housing.

fields.public_field_1_en:
You selected repurpose public land to build housing!
Implementing this strategy in the Bay Area is estimated to produce between 1,000 and 2,000 new homes each year.
While this covers just a small fraction of the projected need for new housing in the region, these new homes tend to be more affordable than the average home in the region.
fields.public_field_2_en: Repurpose public land
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.

fields.public_field_1_en:
You selected transform aging malls into neighborhoods!
Implementing this strategy in the Bay Area is estimated to produce between 3,000 and 6,000 new homes per year.
Additionally, new stores and other workplaces in the new neighborhoods are expected to employ almost twice as many people as were employed when the malls were in operation.
fields.public_field_2_en: Transform aging malls
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.

fields.public_field_1_en: You hang up the phone and check your notifications. There’s a healthy debate happening on social media right now about housing policy in the neighboring town.
fields.public_field_2_en: Let’s see what they’re saying.

fields.public_field_1_en: John
fields.public_field_2_en: Transit and higher density housing make sense together.

fields.public_field_1_en: John
fields.public_field_2_en: We should change current zoning regulations to make it possible to build duplexes and apartments within walking distance of transit, instead of single-family houses.

fields.public_field_1_en: John
fields.public_field_2_en: Existing homes wouldn’t necessarily be rebuilt, but it gives property owners the option.

fields.public_field_1_en: John
fields.public_field_2_en: Some neighborhoods in Bayville have better schools, more parks, and better transportation options.

fields.public_field_1_en: John
fields.public_field_2_en: Unfortunately, these same neighborhoods tend to have high housing costs, meaning only those that can afford to live there have access to these opportunities.

fields.public_field_1_en: John
fields.public_field_2_en: If we allowed for more affordable housing in these neighborhoods, people of all walks of life could have the chance to benefit from these resources.
fields.public_field_3_en: These ideas could work for Bayville!

fields.public_field_1_en: Which policy would you choose to guide future development in your town?
fields.public_field_2_en: Allow affordable housing in high resource areas
fields.public_field_3_en: Allow for the construction of mixed-income housing in high-opportunity areas - places with quality schools or other resources linked to better life outcomes.
fields.public_field_4_en: This could connect more low- and moderate-income families to these resources and in turn improve life outcomes.
fields.public_field_5_en: Opponents say building affordable housing in high-opportunity areas is expensive and would result in a smaller number of affordable housing units being built overall.
fields.public_field_8_en: Allow diverse housing around transit stops
fields.public_field_9_en: Pass state legislation requiring areas within a 10-minute walk of any rail station to be rezoned to allow for apartments and duplexes.
fields.public_field_10_en: This could provide more people with access to transit while also generating ridership for the rail system.
fields.public_field_11_en: Opponents say luxury development near rail stations would increase nearby housing costs and could result in displacement of lower-income residents.

fields.public_field_1_en:
You selected allow affordable housing in high resource areas!
Implementing this strategy in the Bay Area is estimated to produce affordable housing for between 100 and 400 households each year within high resource neighborhoods.
While this represents a relatively small share of all new affordable units, residents of these neighborhoods may expect to benefit from a lack of concentrated poverty and easier access to amenities like parks and quality schools. Unfortunately, this policy is unpopular with some residents of those high resource neighborhoods, which could hurt your chances of re-election next term.
fields.public_field_2_en: Allow affordable housing in high resource areas
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.

fields.public_field_1_en:
You selected allow diverse housing around transit stops!
Implementing this strategy in the Bay Area is estimated to produce housing for between 20,000 and 40,000 households located within a ten minute walk of frequent transit service.
Building housing close to transit is likely to have a number of secondary benefits, including decreases in individual transportation costs and greenhouse gas emissions from transportation.
However, a group of people that already lived close to transit stops have written to you to express concerns that they will be displaced by luxury development and rising housing costs on their blocks.
fields.public_field_2_en: Diverse housing around transit stops
fields.public_field_2_meta_description: The name of the strategy that will be shown in the graph/chart/summary of how people voted.

fields.public_field_1_en: Welcome to Bayville
fields.public_field_2_en: Bayville is a fictional mid-sized city in the very real Bay Area. It’s a great place to live, but life here does have its challenges.

fields.public_field_1_en: Bayville has challenges
fields.public_field_2_en: Traffic congestion, housing affordability, a declining share of jobs in middle-wage industries, and neighborhoods at risk of sea level rise are all problems facing the residents today.

fields.public_field_1_en: The future is uncertain
fields.public_field_2_en: In the future, residents may also be confronted with damage from a major earthquake, experience a global economic recession, or witness the widespread adoption of self-driving cars.

fields.public_field_1_en: Congratulations
fields.public_field_2_en:
How will Bayville prepare for the future that lies ahead?
That’s up to you!
You were just elected mayor.

fields.public_field_1_en: Your challenge
fields.public_field_2_en:
As mayor, you will develop a long-range plan that charts the course for housing, transportation, environmental resilience, and economic development for your town through the year 2050.
You'll receive policy proposals from advisors and helpful residents and choose your top priorities.

fields.public_field_1_en: Instructions
fields.public_field_2_en: You'll have a budget of 100 coins for each of the four topic areas, representing the cost and political difficulty of enacting each policy. Be careful not to go over budget!

fields.public_field_1_en: One more thing before we start...
fields.public_field_2_en: Please answer a few questions so that we can better understand who our new mayor is.
